posts.post_content:
Read that ruling. Let's apply the same principles to other cards.  
  
[Maelstrom Pulse](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Maelstrom Pulse): Most permanents are lands, so this card probably isn't that useful.  
[Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade): 15-20% of creatures are black, so this is nearly unplayable.  
[Treachery](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Treachery): Some creatures have effects that are independent of controller so this is worthless.  
[Vindicate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vindicate): Can't kill Emrakul, bin it.

Posted By: BegleOne (6/8/2011 4:31:10 PM)

posts.post_content:
Examples of auras for which it matters who controls them:  
[Firebreathing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Firebreathing): The activated ability is on the enchantment, not on the creature, so you decide whether to pump up the enchanted creature (and will presumably decide not to).  
[Control Magic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Control Magic): It says "you control enchanted creature", and who "you" is changes. So in this case you'd steal the creature, too.  
[Vow of Wildness](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vow of Wildness): The "you" in "can't attack you" is the enchantment's controller, so now that creature can't attack you, but can attack whomever the previous controller was.  
[Prison Term](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prison Term): The controller is the one who decides whether to move it to a new creature.  
  
Examples of auras for which it doesn't matter:  
[Unholy Strength](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unholy Strength), [Rancor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rancor), [Power of Fire](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Power of Fire), [Arrest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arrest)
posts.html:
Examples of auras for which it matters who controls them:
Firebreathing: The activated ability is on the enchantment, not on the creature, so you decide whether to pump up the enchanted creature (and will presumably decide not to).
Control Magic: It says "you control enchanted creature", and who "you" is changes. So in this case you'd steal the creature, too.
Vow of Wildness: The "you" in "can't attack you" is the enchantment's controller, so now that creature can't attack you, but can attack whomever the previous controller was.
Prison Term: The controller is the one who decides whether to move it to a new creature.

Examples of auras for which it doesn't matter:
Unholy Strength, Rancor, Power of Fire, Arrest

Posted By: Salient (7/28/2013 8:08:37 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Basically you get to control or change what the enchantment or aura does. You can deny opponents their auras that require activated abilities to be effective. Auras with static and triggered abilities won't really matter, unless they affect "you" somehow. Regular enchantments are usually static, but also usually penalize your "opponent" and benefit "you" (the controller).
posts.html:

Regular enchantments are usually static, but also usually penalize your "opponent" and benefit "you" (the controller).

posts.post_content:
Broken when used with [Flash](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flash) while [Enchanted Evening](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Enchanted Evening) is in play, tipping the game so much in your favor that it's almost impossible to recover from. Almost not worth playing in any deck that doesn't involve that enchantment.  
  
The look of everyone else's face on the table as you reach over and grab all their lands is kind of priceless, though the novelty of it wears off eventually.
